value: Warfarin is an anticoagulant medication used to prevent blood clots in individuals with conditions such as atrial fibrillation, deep vein thrombosis, or pulmonary embolism, where the underlying aetiology involves disruption of the normal blood coagulation cascade.
Warfarin use is relatively common, and cases are readily identifiable in real-world healthcare data due to its widespread use for various thromboembolic conditions.
65 to 80 (Individuals typically present later in life as the incidence of atrial fibrillation and other thromboembolic risk factors increases with age.)
55% to 65% (Men are slightly more prone to conditions like atrial fibrillation and vascular disease, which often necessitate warfarin therapy.)
50% to 75% (Mortality is influenced by the underlying conditions requiring warfarin therapy and the effectiveness of anticoagulation management.)

Overlap with acetaminophen (20-40%) and morphine (5-15%) may occur due to their use for pain management, while overlap with prostate-specific antigen testing (10-30%) might be observed in older men. There would be little overlap with users of other anticoagulants.

Typically, individuals may be on acetaminophen and morphine for pain management prior to starting warfarin for a thromboembolic event; prostate-specific antigen testing may occur before or concurrently with warfarin initiation as part of routine health screenings. All of the cohorts would be entered with a median timing difference of approximately 1 year.

Atrial fibrillation, Coronary artery disease, Heart failure, Deep vein thrombosis, Pulmonary embolism, Stroke, Hypertension, Diabetes mellitus, Chronic kidney disease, Peripheral artery disease (These comorbidities are frequently associated with conditions that either predispose individuals to thromboembolic events or share common risk factors with conditions requiring anticoagulation.)

Bleeding, Bruising, Hematoma, Hematuria, Melena, Epistaxis, Gingival bleeding, Fatigue, Weakness, Dizziness (These signs and symptoms are indicative of potential bleeding complications associated with warfarin's anticoagulant effects.)

Aspirin, Acetaminophen, Beta blockers, Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, Diuretics, Statins, Antiplatelet agents, Opioid analgesics, Proton pump inhibitors, Thyroid hormones (These medications are commonly prescribed to manage co-existing cardiovascular conditions, pain, and other age-related comorbidities in patients on warfarin.)

Acetaminophen use encompasses individuals taking the medication for its analgesic and antipyretic properties, often to manage pain or fever associated with various underlying conditions. Its widespread use is primarily driven by its availability as an over-the-counter medication for self-treatment of mild to moderate pain and fever.
Acetaminophen use is very common. Cases are easily identifiable in real-world health care data due to its widespread use and documentation in prescriptions and patient records.
45 to 65 (Individuals typically present in middle to older age, as these age groups experience more musculoskeletal pain and chronic conditions requiring pain relief.)

45% to 55% (The proportion of males and females using acetaminophen is expected to be relatively balanced, with a slight tendency for higher usage in females due to a higher prevalence of certain pain conditions.)
60% to 85% (Acetaminophen use is related to the underlying disease, rather than being a direct cause of death, so survival is dependent on the condition being treated.)

The overlap with warfarin is expected to be low (5-15%) as they may be cautioned against concomitant use. The overlap with morphine (10-20%) may be present in some patients for pain management. There is little expected overlap with measurement of prostate specific antigen level (<5%) because this lab test is not related to the conditions for which acetaminophen is usually prescribed.

Individuals may enter the acetaminophen cohort first for pain management. If they also appear in the morphine cohort, they are likely to enter the acetaminophen cohort first, followed by morphine if pain is not well controlled with acetaminophen (days to months later). If they also appear in the warfarin cohort, the timing of entry is less predictable, but could be concomitant or separate by months or years, depending on when anticoagulation becomes necessary. For measurement of prostate specific antigen level, the entry to the acetaminophen cohort would typically precede the measurement by years, although there is no direct relationship.

Hypertension, Osteoarthritis, Diabetes Mellitus, Ischemic Heart Disease, Chronic Kidney Disease, Heart Failure, Depression, Anxiety, Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease, Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (These comorbidities are common in the general adult population who are more likely to use acetaminophen for pain management related to these conditions.)

Pain, Fever, Headache, Muscle aches, Joint pain, Sore throat, Back pain, Toothache, Inflammation, General discomfort (These signs and symptoms are commonly associated with conditions for which acetaminophen is used for symptomatic relief.)

Aspirin, Ibuprofen, Naproxen, Omeprazole, Atorvastatin, Metformin, Lisinopril, Amlodipine, Hydrochlorothiazide, Simvastatin (These medications are commonly used to treat conditions for which acetaminophen might be used to manage associated pain or fever.)

Morphine use indicates the administration of a potent opioid analgesic, typically prescribed for the management of moderate to severe pain arising from acute injuries, post-operative states, chronic conditions like cancer, or palliative care. The aetiology of morphine use is directly linked to the underlying condition causing pain, as it does not treat the disease itself but rather alleviates the associated discomfort.
Morphine use is relatively common, especially in hospital settings and among patients with chronic pain; therefore, cases are readily identifiable in real-world healthcare data.
60 to 75 (Individuals typically present for morphine prescription later in life, when chronic pain conditions and cancer become more prevalent.)

40% to 60% (The proportion of males and females prescribed morphine is likely to be relatively balanced, although there may be a slight predominance in males due to higher rates of certain injuries and conditions.)
20% to 60% (Five-year survival is highly variable and dependent on the underlying condition requiring morphine; patients with cancer or severe heart conditions will have lower survival rates.)

Overlap with user_of_warfarin is expected to be 5-15% because both are more common in older patients. Overlap with user_of_acetaminophen is expected to be 20-40% as both are common analgesics. Overlap with measurement_of_prostate_specific_antigen_level is expected to be 5-15% as this test is specific to older men who may also have pain conditions.

Individuals might enter the acetaminophen cohort roughly concurrently with morphine (within days or weeks) for pain management. Entry into the warfarin cohort might precede or follow morphine initiation by months or years, depending on the onset of conditions requiring anticoagulation. Entry into the measurement_of_prostate_specific_antigen_level cohort will likely precede morphine use by years as screening guidelines suggest regular testing from age 50, whilst morphine use is more common later in life.

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, Osteoarthritis, Depression, Anxiety, Hypertension, Diabetes mellitus, Ischemic heart disease, Back pain, Neuropathic pain, Cancer (These comorbidities are commonly seen in individuals requiring morphine due to the increased risk of chronic pain conditions and other health issues that often necessitate opioid pain management.)

Pain, Constipation, Nausea, Vomiting, Sedation, Dizziness, Confusion, Respiratory depression, Pruritus, Urinary retention (These signs and symptoms are commonly associated with morphine use due to its effects on the central nervous system and gastrointestinal tract.)

Acetaminophen, Ibuprofen, Gabapentin, Pregabalin, Amitriptyline, Sertraline, Amlodipine, Metoprolol, Omeprazole, Warfarin (These medications are frequently co-prescribed with morphine to manage pain, treat side effects, or address underlying comorbid conditions.)

Measurement of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level is often conducted to screen for prostate cancer, a disease where abnormal cells grow in the prostate gland, or to monitor its progression or recurrence. Elevated PSA levels can indicate prostate cancer but can also be due to other conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia or prostatitis.
PSA testing is frequently performed in older men, especially in primary care settings; expect to identify a substantial number of cases in real-world health care data.
60 to 75 (PSA testing is more common in older men as the risk of prostate cancer increases with age.)
99% to 100% (PSA testing is almost exclusively performed in males due to the physiology of the prostate gland.)

60% to 95% (Survival rates vary widely depending on the underlying cause of PSA elevation and the specific treatments received, but can reflect the overall health of the individual and the successful management of prostate cancer if present.)

Overlap with warfarin is expected in 5-15% of cases due to age-related conditions; acetaminophen use could overlap in 20-40% of cases for pain management; morphine overlap is less common at 1-5%, typically for severe pain. These overlaps reflect the management of various conditions alongside potential prostate issues.

Individuals may be on warfarin, acetaminophen, or morphine for years before PSA testing due to other conditions, so entry into those cohorts is likely to precede entry into the PSA testing cohort by months to years. Conversely, some may start these medications after a concerning PSA result, leading to entry into the other cohorts after the PSA testing cohort.

Hypertension, Hyperlipidemia, Type 2 diabetes mellitus, Benign prostatic hyperplasia, Osteoarthritis, Ischemic heart disease, Chronic kidney disease, Depression, Obesity, Erectile dysfunction (These comorbidities are common in older men and can be related to lifestyle factors, age-related physiological changes, and hormonal influences.)

No symptoms (asymptomatic), Frequent urination, Weak urine stream, Nocturia, Erectile dysfunction, Lower back pain, Hip pain, Blood in urine, Bone pain, Urinary retention (Many individuals are asymptomatic, but these signs and symptoms can be related to prostate enlargement or potential prostate cancer and lead to PSA testing.)

Statins, Antihypertensives, Alpha-blockers, 5-alpha reductase inhibitors, Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, Antidepressants, Oral hypoglycemics, Aspirin, Vitamin D supplements, Bisphosphonates (These medications reflect the common comorbidities and age-related conditions prevalent in individuals undergoing PSA testing.)
